t: Job 15
Eliphaz Accuses Job of Folly
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
“Should*pn a wise man answer with empty knowledge, And*ld fill himself with the east wind?
Should*ld he reason with unprofitable talk, Or*ld by speeches with which he can do no good?
Yes,*ld you cast off fear, And*ld restrain prayer before God.
For*ld your iniquity teaches your mouth, And*ld you choose the tongue of the crafty.
Your*ld own mouth condemns you, and not I; Yes,*ld your own lips testify against you.
“Are*iln you the first man who*i was born? Or*ld were you made before the hills?
Have*ld you heard the counsel of God? Do*ld you limit wisdom to yourself?
What*ld do you know that we do not know? What*ild do you understand that is*i not in us?
Both*ld the gray-haired and the aged are*i among us, Much*ld older than your father.
Are*ild the consolations of God too small for you, And*ld the word spoken*i gently with you?
Why*ld does your heart carry you away, And*ld what do your eyes wink at,
That*ld you turn your spirit against God, And*ld let such*i words go out of your mouth?
“What*ln is*i man, that he could be pure? And*ld he*i who*i is*i born of a woman, that he could be righteous?
If*ld God*i puts no trust in His saints, And*ld the heavens are not pure in His sight,
How*ld much less man, who*i is*i abominable and filthy, Who*ld drinks iniquity like water!
“I*ln will tell you, hear me; What*ld I have seen I will declare,
What*ld wise men have told, Not*ld hiding anything*i received*i from their fathers,
To*ld whom alone the land was given, And*ld no alien passed among them:
The*ld wicked man writhes with pain all his*i days, And*ld the number of years is hidden from the oppressor.
Dreadful*ld sounds are*i in his ears; In*ld prosperity the destroyer comes upon him.
He*ld does not believe that he will return from darkness, For*ld a sword is waiting for him.
He*ld wanders about for bread, saying,*i ‘Where is*i it?’*i He*ld knows that a day of darkness is ready at his hand.
Trouble*ld and anguish make him afraid; They*ld overpower him, like a king ready for battle.
For*ld he stretches out his hand against God, And*ld acts defiantly against the Almighty,
Running*ld stubbornly against Him With*ld his strong, embossed shield.
“Though*ln he has covered his face with his fatness, And*ld made his*i waist heavy with fat,
He*ld dwells in desolate cities, In*ld houses which no one inhabits, Which*ld are destined to become ruins.
He*ld will not be rich, Nor*ld will his wealth continue, Nor*ld will his possessions overspread the earth.
He*ld will not depart from darkness; The*ld flame will dry out his branches, And*ld by the breath of His mouth he will go away.
Let*ld him not trust in futile things,*i deceiving himself, For*ld futility will be his reward.
It*ld will be accomplished before his time, And*ld his branch will not be green.
He*ld will shake off his unripe grape like a vine, And*ld cast off his blossom like an olive tree.
For*ld the company of hypocrites will*i be*i barren, And*ld fire will consume the tents of bribery.
They*ld conceive trouble and bring forth futility; Their*ld womb prepares deceit.”
